entry.title: UX and application development with AI at ASUG Tech Connect 2025 a companion event to SAP TechEd
entry.content:
This year, SAP TechEd has several options to allow you to learn about the latest SAP technologies and how to apply them to your organization. In addition to TechEd in Berlin and the virtual option, there are ‚ÄúSAP TechEd On Tour‚Äù events in Louisville, Sydney, and Bangalore. In this post, I‚Äôll share the sessions on application development and user experience that we are presenting at ASUG Tech Connect in Louisville, Kentucky. As you would expect many have AI -assisted capabilities to make both business users and developers more productive.

 

At ASUG Tech Connect, we have both lectures and hands-on workshops.

Lectures are a chance to hear from SAP experts and have your questions answered in the room.

Extensibility with ABAP Cloud and AI in SAP Cloud ERP (Jens Weiler)
Explore on-stack key user and developer tools in the ABAP Cloud development model, now enhanced with generative AI. Extend standard apps and manage custom ones in SAP Cloud ERP and explore transactional, analytical, and integration use cases like the extensibility AI assistant, queries for analytical SAP Fiori apps, and SQL services.
Tuesday, November 4, 2025, 11:15 AM-12:05 PM

What‚Äôs Next: AI-First Innovations in SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Suite (Ullas Holla, Peter Spielvogel)
Get a fast-paced look at how SAP is embedding AI and delivering cross-suite innovations that break down silos and speed up decision-making. We‚Äôll cover the latest highlights from releases of SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Suite‚Äîplus give you a sneak peek at what‚Äôs coming in 2026 and beyond.
Tuesday, November 4, 2025, 3:30 PM-4:20 PM

Customer Show and Tell: From CDS View to Fiori Launchpad: Full-Stack Development with Eclipse ADT with Naturipe (Brian Galloway, Dario Cruz)
This session covers the end-to-end development workflow in the RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition environment using Eclipse ABAP Development Tools (ADT). It demonstrates how to define a data source and expose it via a CDS view, enabling consumption through SAP Fiori elements, Eclipse ADT, and Postman. A live demo illustrates the creation of a simple SAPUI5 application that consumes the same OData service and is deployed to the SAP Fiori Launchpad, showcasing full-stack integration from backend data modeling to frontend delivery.
Wednesday, November 5, 2025, 8:00 AM-9:30 AM

Using Generative AI to Accelerate SAP Fiori App Development (Ullas Holla)
AI changes everything, especially for developing business applications. See how SAP‚Äôs latest coding agents let you build SAP Fiori elements apps using a conversational interface. Create apps using Joule, including a CAP service, sample data, and SAPUI5 customizations.
Wednesday, November 5, 2025, 4:10 PM-5:00 PM

Creating Better User Experiences with AI-Powered SAP Fiori Apps (Peter Spielvogel)
Discover how the latest AI features in SAP Fiori apps enhance user productivity and streamline onboarding. Starting with My Home and diving into commonly used SAP Fiori apps, see how AI simplifies information access, supports informed business decisions, and fosters seamless collaboration. Explore how conversational interactions are making SAP more intuitive than ever.
Thursday, November 6, 2025, 4:15 PM-5:05 PM

Hands-on workshops give you the opportunity to test the latest SAP innovations and gain access to the same tools and technologies we use to build apps for SAP S/4HANA.

Hands-on Lab: Get Started with ABAP Cloud for Classic ABAP Developers
Familiar with classic ABAP development? Explore how similar development works with ABAP Cloud using the ABAP RESTful application programming model. Use ABAP Cloud to build cloud-ready business apps, services, and extensions that follow clean core principles by default‚Äîon SAP Business Technology Platform and in any edition of SAP S/4HANA.
Tuesday, November 4, 2025, 1:10 PM-3:10 PM

Hands-on Lab: Explore Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities
Learn how to develop transactional applications using the ABAP RESTful application model in ABAP Cloud while leveraging Joule capabilities for ABAP developers.
Wednesday, November 5, 2025, 8:00 AM-10:00 AM

Hands-on Lab: Build On-Stack Extensions with ABAP Cloud in SAP Cloud ERP
Discover how to build extensions, applications, and services with the ABAP Cloud development model, using the ABAP RESTful application programming model and generative AI. You can explore how to extend standard SAP applications, consume public SAP APIs, and build new apps and services from scratch while getting practical insights through exercises
Wednesday, November 5, 2025, 1:00 PM-3:00 PM

Hands-on Lab: Modernize Classic Extensions for Clean Core in SAP Cloud ERP Private
Practice clean core extensibility in SAP Cloud ERP Private. Learn how to govern clean core development using the ABAP test cockpit, and how to use the ABAP Cloud development model and clean core extensibility principles to modernize your custom on-stack extensions.
Thursday, November 6, 2025, 1:00 PM-3:00 PM

Discovery Workshop: Start Your AI Agent Journey by Exploring AI Agent Use Cases 
In this discovery workshop, you will learn how AI Agents function and what makes a strong use case. You will identify and prioritize strategic AI Agent use cases for your business. For your selected use case, you will explore how AI Agent capabilities can address your specific business challenges and learn the next steps for designing and building an AI Agent using the SAP Agent Builder.
Thursday November 6, 2025, 1:00 PM-3:00 PM

I hope you can join us.

entry.title: Activate Joule Studio in 5 Simple Steps
entry.content:
Joule Studio is a capability in SAP Build that allows organizations to create and deploy custom Joule agents and skills that automate workflows and improve efficiency across SAP and non-SAP systems. Currently the Agent Builder offering is in Beta and the Skill Builder  offering is generally available. In this blog, we will focus on activation of the Skill Builder in Joule which is now Generally Available.

Stay updated on the latest Business AI services and activation guides by following the SAP Business AI Onboarding Resource Center

The key pre-requisites to activate Skill Builder with Joule Studio are as follows:-
Access to BTP Global Account with the following entitlements available via Subscription, BTPEA, CPEA or PAYG model

  • SAP Build Process Automation, build-default (Application) plan
  • Joule, foundation (Application)/ standard (Application) plan
  • Active instance of SAP Cloud Identity Services for Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning  

Read more about the service and pre-requisites in these following blogs from our product leaders and managers:

  • Joule Studio is generally available in SAP Build: Empower your business with intelligent automation
  • Build, Deploy, and Extend AI Agents with Joule Studio
  • How to Get Started with Joule Studio

Activating Joule Studio - Skill Builder in 5 Simple Steps

Here is a quick hit video capturing the steps documented below:

 

Onto the Joule. Studio- Skill Builder Activation!

Step 1 - Create a BTP Subaccount and Assign the Entitlements:

Create a subaccount in your BTP Global Account and select region where both Joule, foundation/ standard and Build Process Automation, build-default plans are available. Find the list of regions supported for Joule service at this SAP Help Portal link and Build Process Automation Service at this SAP Help Portal link.

  • Click on Create button on BTP Global Account landing page and select Subaccount option

  • Enter the relevant details including selecting the suitable region and click on Create button

Enable Cloud Foundry Environment

  • Click on Enable Cloud Foundry button on the subaccount landing page

  • Update the details in the window and click on Create button

Create Space in the Cloud Foundry Environment

  • Select the Create Space button that appears after the Cloud Foundry Environment is created

  • Select the relevant roles and click on the Create button

Add Joule and  Build Process Automation entitlements

  • Navigate to Entitlements section from subaccount landing page
  • Click on Edit button

  • Select Add Service Plans button

 

  • Search for Joule in the search bar and select the foundation (Application) plan of the Joule service 

  • Next, search for build process in the search bar and select the build-default (Application) plan from SAP Build Process Automation service
  • Click on  Add 2 Service Plans button to add the entitlements to the relevant subaccount

  • Click on Save button on the Entitlements page

Step 2- Complete Trust Configuration and Activate Build Process Automation (Subaccount):

Create a Trust Configuration to add authentication for application users in the IAS tenant on BTP

  • Navigate to Security > Trust Configuration section under your BTP subaccount
  • Click on Establish Trust button

  • Select the suitable IAS tenant and click on Next button

  • Choose the domain consistent with your BTP account and non-BTP applications and click on the Next button

  • Review and update the relevant parameters in this screen and click on Next button

  • Review the details and click on Finish button

Enable the Build Process Automation Service, build-default plan

  • Navigate to Instances and Subscriptions section under your BTP subaccount and click on Create button

  • Select the SAP Build Process Automation service and build-default plan and click on Create button

  • The service will be created as seen under Subscriptions

Step 3 - Run Joule Booster to Activate Joule Studio Capability Package (Global Account):

Activate Joule Studio Capability Package on SAP Build Process Automation

  • Navigate to your BTP Global Account and select the Boosters section
    • Search for Joule in the search bar and select the Setting Up Joule booster tile

  • Click on Start button

  • After the prerequisites are checked and required entitlements are met, click on Next button 

  • Select the Joule (das-application) plan and the subaccount where Build Process Automation service is activated and click on Next button

  • After selecting the products to be integrated on the following screen and selecting relevant system type option click on Next button. Review Integrating Joule with SAP Solutions help document for more details on pre-requisites for integration with the relevant SAP systems in your organization

  • Select the SAP Build Process Automation option from the Capability Packages dropdown, click on Next button

  • Review the Formation Name and select the correct service instance number - URL from the SAP Build Process Automation System dropdown then click on the Next button

  • Review the details on the final page of the booster and click on Finish button

  • After processing, the Success window appears, click on the Close button after reviewing status

Step 4 - Create Role Collection and Assign Users (Subaccount):

Create Role Collection and assign the role collection the relevant users

  • Navigate to the Subaccount where the Build Process Automation service is installed and navigate to the Role Collections section and click on Create button; Enter the relevant details and click on Create button

  • Select the recently created role collection line item from the list and click on Edit button

  • Select search help option in first empty line item under Roles

  • Enter the search text "das" Application Identifier dropdown, select the right option from the list and select the end_user and extensibility_developer roles from the list below. Click on Add button after selecting the roles

  • Click the Save button for the role collection we created

  • Navigate to Users option under the Security section of the subaccount and click Create button

  • Select the Identity Provider for which the trust configuration was added, add the user details and click on Create button

  • Click on the new user created in the table, navigate to Role Collections section, click on the options(...) and select Assign Role Collections option

  • Select the role collection created in the previous step from the list along with Build Process Automation roles and any other relevant roles and click on the Assign Role Collection button

  • Navigate to Instances and Subscriptions and select the SAP Build Process Automation instance

  • Click on Create after the Build Lobby loads

  • The Joule Skill option should now be available for you to create custom Joule Skills

Step 5 - Build Your First Custom Joule Skill:

Follow the Build custom Joule skills for SAP and non-SAP systems using Joule Studio mission to get started with building your custom skills on Joule Studio.

Congratulations, you are all set to start building Custom Skills with the Skill Builder on Joule Studio!

Please do leave kudos and comments as feedback to help us keep improving the quality of our content.

Additional Resources 

Architecture Overview

Joule Skill Demo Video

Smart Advisory Companion ‚Äì Inspiration Video

üß≠ Product Tour

FAQ

entry.title: Unlocking Visibility with ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù feature in Process Visibility
entry.content:
Introduction

In today‚Äôs fast-paced business world, not every process follows a straight path, or even connects at all. Yet, enterprises still need end-to-end visibility.

Enter SAP‚Äôs powerful capability in Process Visibility: the ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù feature.

Whether you‚Äôre managing HR workflows or procurement cycles, this feature offers flexibility to monitor and analyze non-correlated processes together ‚Äî all within a single dashboard.

 

Why Does ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù feature Matter?

Not all business processes are tightly linked. Many operate in parallel within the same business domain but have no direct interaction.

Example:

  • Hiring vs. Retirement
  • Promotion vs. Equipment Provisioning

They all fall under Human Resources, yet they function independently. Still, business leaders need visibility across all these activities, ideally through one Visibility Scenario dashboard.

That‚Äôs exactly what Process Visibility's ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù feature enables.

 

Building the Foundation: Process Groups

SAP Process Visibility lets you group processes - correlated or non-correlated into Process Groups for better monitoring.

Two main configurations:

  1. Correlated Processes (e.g., Hiring ‚Üî Equipment Provisioning)
    • Processes are connected in sequence.
    • Define connections between them within a process group.
  2. Non-Correlated Processes (e.g., Promotion Change, Retirement)
    • Processes run independently but still need unified tracking.
    • Create separate process groups and map common attributes to view them cohesively.

Note: A default Process Group is automatically created. You can edit or create new ones depending on your scenario.

 

Step-by-Step: Enabling Non-Correlated Process Tracking

  • Adding Process Participants:

In your Visibility Scenario Editor ‚Üí Processes tab ‚Üí Add the processes that need to either be correlated or not correlated, as process participants.

In this example, we have created a Visibility Scenario for HR Department. We are adding 4 processes as process participants ‚Äì Hiring, Promotion Change, Retirement and Equipment Provisioning. In this scenario, Hiring and Equipment Provisioning are related processes, while Promotion Change and Retirement are independent processes.

  • Enable the No Correlation Feature

As we have processes that are not correlated, we will have to enable this feature.
In your Visibility Scenario Editor ‚Üí General tab ‚Üí Enable ‚ÄúVisibility Scenario to Include Non-Correlated Processes‚Äù

This unlocks side-by-side tracking of independent workflows.

  • Create Process Groups

Note: A default Process Group is automatically created with all the process participants. You can edit or create new ones depending on your scenario.

Example:

In this example, the default process group is updated with Hiring and Equipment Provisioning processes. As the process group contains more than one process, a connection is defined for these processes.

Then we create 2 process groups:

  • One group for Promotion Change
  • Another for Retirement

These are the independent process that are not related. For the individual processes, new process groups are created, one for each process. As there is only one process in each of these process groups, there no need to define the connection type.

 

  • Map Attributes for Unified Tracking

Once you‚Äôve created process groups for your non-correlated processes, the next step is to unify how you view them. You can do them in the Attributes -> Context tab

Choose Map Attributes to map the attributes of the processes across process groups:

In the Map Attributes dialog box, select the Source Attribute and the Mapped Attribute from the drop-down list. You can map shared attributes like Employee ID or Department etc., The source attributes will then be visible in the Visibility Scenario Instances application and the Mapped Attributes are hidden.

You can choose Add Attribute button to map more attributes.

Choose Save.

This ensures all mapped attributes appear cohesively in your Visibility Scenario Instances application.

  • Finally release and deploy.

 

Business Value

Streamlined Monitoring: See all relevant processes, even if unlinked - in one dashboard.
Accurate Insights: Focus on meaningful groupings, not rigid process chains.
Scalability: Easily manage hybrid landscapes of connected and standalone processes.

 

Final Thoughts

The ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù feature in SAP Process Visibility is more than a technical enhancement, it‚Äôs a strategic enabler.
It empowers organizations to track and optimize processes the way they truly operate, not just how systems connect them.

Whether your workflows are integrated, hybrid, or standalone, SAP Process Visibility ensures you never lose sight of what matters most: business outcomes!

entry.title: Streamline Your Migration to SBPA with the ‚ÄòNo Correlation‚Äô Feature in Process Visibility
entry.content:
Introduction

As businesses modernise their operations, many customers are migrating from SAP Workflow Management to SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA).

This migration is a key step in digital transformation, but it also introduces challenges when processes built on different technologies need to coexist and remain visible together.

That‚Äôs where SAP‚Äôs ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù feature in Process Visibility steps in, making it possible to track legacy and new processes in a unified view, without data duplication or reporting disruption.

 

The Migration Challenge

During migration, organisations often face:

  • Technology gaps between BTP Workflow and SAP Build Process Automation [SBPA] processes.
  • Disconnected visibility between legacy and new workflows.
  • Reporting inconsistency when both environments run in parallel.

 

How ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù Simplifies Migration to SAP Build Process Automation

Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôve exported a Visibility Scenario ‚ÄúInsights on Capital Expenditure Process‚Äù from SAP Workflow Management and imported it into your SBPA project and you have re-modelled the process ‚ÄúCapital Expenditure Scenario‚Äù in SAP Build Process Automation as shown below:

Now, both your legacy Workflow and your newly built SBPA process serve the same business purpose, but run on different technologies.

By enabling ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù feature, you can:

  • Create separate Process Groups for each process participant (BTP Workflow & SAP Build Process Automation Process).
  • Use attribute mapping to unify common fields (e.g., Request Number, Employee ID etc.,).
  • Achieve a single, unified dashboard view in the Visibility Scenario Instances app.

 

Step-by-Step: Applying ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù for Migration to SAP Build Process Automation

  • Adding Process Participants:

In your Visibility Scenario Editor, add the Newly Modelled SBPA Process as a Process Participant:

  • Enable the Feature:

In your Visibility Scenario Editor ‚Üí General tab ‚Üí Enable ‚ÄúVisibility Scenario to Include Non-Correlated Processes‚Äù

  • Create Separate Process Groups
    • One for BTP Workflow from Workflow Management
    • One for SBPA Process
      Both run independently but share the same business context.

Note: A default Process Group is automatically created with all the process participants. You can edit or create new ones depending on your scenario.

  • Map Common Attributes

Under Attributes ‚Üí Context tab, map shared business fields like Request ID, CAPEX cost, or Employee ID etc.,
This ensures seamless/unified view of both legacy and SBPA processes in a single Process Visibility dashboard.

Now that we have completed the configuration, the Source attributes would appear in the Process Visibility dashboard View and the Mapped attributes would be hidden.

 

Business Impact

Unified Process Visibility: Track historical (BTP Workflows) and new (SBPA processes) in one view.
Smooth Migration: Maintain operational reporting continuity during migration.
No Data Duplication: Map common attributes intelligently for consistent analytics.
Future-Ready Operations: Enable co-existence between multiple automation technologies on SAP BTP.

 

Final Thoughts

The ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù feature acts as a bridge during migration ‚Äî helping organisations maintain visibility, accuracy, and performance as they move from SAP Workflow Management to SAP Build Process Automation.

It‚Äôs a practical example of how SAP‚Äôs intelligent automation tools ensure continuity while paving the way for innovation.

With ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù feature, you can confidently modernise your process automation landscape without losing sight of your data or insights.

The result is a clean, unified view in the Visibility Scenario Instances dashboard. This allows business users to continue tracking historical and newly migrated processes together, without disrupting reporting or analytics.

entry.title: Empowering Process Visibility with Step Navigation Links
entry.content:
Introduction

In the world of process automation and monitoring, visibility is power‚Äîbut actionability is the real game-changer. That‚Äôs why SAP Process Visibility offers a powerful feature that lets you go beyond viewing process steps to actually interacting with them: Step Navigation Links.

With just one click, users can jump directly from a step in the Process Workspace to the relevant task in the source application [Eg., My Inbox, SAP Task Center etc.,] streamlining issue resolution, approvals, and decision-making.

Let‚Äôs explore how easy it is to set this up.

 

What Are Step Navigation Links?

Step navigation links allow you to embed deep links in specific steps of a process path so users can quickly navigate to external apps like My Inbox, SAP Task Center, or any custom application to take action or see more details.

This bridges the gap between process monitoring and process execution.

 

Real-World Example

Imagine you're tracking a Capital Expenditure Approval process in SAP Process Visibility. One of the steps is a pending task that a manager needs to approve in My Inbox.

With Step Navigation Links, you can:

  • Display a clickable link right on the process step in the Process Path view.
  • Direct users to the exact task instance in 'My Inbox'.
  • Eliminate the need for users to search manually or switch between systems.

 

How to Configure Step Navigation Links

A quick step-by-step guide to configure step navigation links in your visibility scenario can be found in our SAP Help Documentation : Configure Step Navigation Links.

 

Example: Deep Linking to My Inbox

Steps:

  • In the visibility scenario editor, navigate to the Processes tab and choose the SAP Build Process Automation process for which you want to configure step navigation link.
  • Under Steps and Events section, select the required step from the list and choose ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù.

  • In the Edit Step dialog box, navigate to the Link tab, and enable the Enable Link Configurations toggle button to configure the navigation link and update the Event, Path and Link Text as shown in the below example.

Here‚Äôs a practical example of how to create a dynamic link:

Copy the Original URL from 'My Inbox':

In the copied URL, replace the InstanceID with {stepInstanceId}, which will be dynamically retrieved from Process Visibility

Final URL:

This ensures that the link dynamically pulls the correct step instance ID when viewed in Process Visibility.

 

Why This Matters

Step Navigation Links bring real-time actionability to your process monitoring tools. Instead of just seeing that something is pending, users can click directly into the task, speeding up response times and improving collaboration across teams.

They‚Äôre especially valuable in scenarios like:

  • Procurement Approvals
  • HR Workflows
  • (Or) Any custom business process.

 

Final Thoughts

Configuring Step Navigation Links in SAP Process Visibility enables a dynamic, interactive experience. Whether you're managing tasks in My Inbox, SAP Task Center, or custom apps, these deep links let you act without leaving your process dashboard.

It‚Äôs a small setup with big impact‚Äîboosting productivity, responsiveness, and user satisfaction.

entry.content:

entry.title: SAP TechEd 2025: Your Must-Attend Sessions on SAP BTP
entry.content:
It feels like I came back from SAP Connect just yesterday, but SAP TechEd is now less than two weeks away. In addition to the virtual event, SAP TechEd 2025 will be held in five different cities and offer hundreds of sessions. Here‚Äôs my guide to the must-attend sessions for AI agents, SAP Business Technology Platform architecture, Extensions, and Integration across the world, as well as Virtual.

 

Why SAP TechEd 2025 is Unmissable

The enterprise technology landscape is evolving at breakneck speed, and SAP TechEd 2025 promises to be the defining moment where cutting-edge innovation meets hands-on expertise. This is the leading event for developers and IT professionals ready to explore SAP's most transformative technologies and emerge with skills that deliver measurable impact from day one.

SAP TechEd

  • SAP TechEd Berlin (November 4-6, 2025) offers the flagship in-person experience where you'll connect directly with SAP experts, participate in hands-on workshops, and build lasting professional relationships within the global SAP community
  • SAP TechEd Virtual (November 4-6, 2025) provides the same high-quality technical content online for free for maximum accessibility, allowing you to explore the latest innovations in application development, integration, data, and AI from anywhere in the world

SAP TechEd on Tour

The SAP TechEd on Tour series delivers localized, immersive experiences tailored to regional technical communities. Each event combines the core SAP TechEd experience with region-specific insights, local expert networks, and formats optimized for different technical communities and career advancement goals.

  • ASUG Tech Connect in Louisville, KY (November 4-6) focuses on practical skills for North American practitioners
  • Mastering SAP in Sydney, Australia (November 12-14) brings together Asia-Pacific technical experts for intensive learning and networking
  • SAP TechEd on Tour Bangalore, India (November 25-26) offers hands-on workshops and certification boot camps designed for the thriving Indian developer community
  • DSAG TechXchange 2026 in Hamburg, Germany (March 19) provides specialized DevOps-focused sessions for European technical professionals

 

Must-Attend Sessions at SAP TechEd 2025

Don't miss these carefully curated sessions that will give you the deepest insights into SAP's technology roadmap and hands-on skills you can immediately apply. Here are my top recommendations for SAP TechEd Berlin, Virtual, and ASUG Tech Connect, organized by city and focus area:

SAP TechEd Berlin & Virtual

üèóÔ∏è Platform Strategy & Architecture

  • ST126 | Understanding our strategy for SAP BTP: The big picture: Get the executive overview of SAP's unified platform strategy directly from the Head of BTP Product Management. This is essential for understanding how all SAP technologies connect. 
    üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì BERLIN | üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì VIRTUAL

  • XP100 | Accelerate adoption of SAP Business Technology Platform with confidence: Learn practical implementation approaches using SAP's Architecture Center and Discovery Center resources. Perfect for planning your BTP adoption strategy. 
    üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì BERLIN | üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì VIRTUAL

ü§ñ AI & AI Agents

  • AD202 | Orchestrating enterprise automation with custom AI agents: Build custom AI agents from scratch in Joule Studio and integrate them with SAP Build Process Automation. Features real customer use cases from Uniper Energy
    üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì BERLIN | üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì VIRTUAL

  • AD819 | What's new for process automation, Joule skills, and agents in SAP Build: Learn how enterprise automation is evolving from structured workflows to intelligent, autonomous experiences, and how Joule Studio supports custom skill and agent creation for AI-driven process transformation.
    üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì BERLIN | üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì VIRTUAL

  • AI102 | Boosting business efficiency with AI innovations in document processing: Discover how SAP Document AI automates structured and unstructured document processing with cutting-edge AI technologies. 
    üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì BERLIN | üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì VIRTUAL

  • AI105 | Building custom AI agents and skills with Joule Studio: You can learn how to create, deploy, and manage agents tailored to your business needs‚Äîfeaturing live demos and a walkthrough of key capabilities for developers and IT teams.
    üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì BERLIN | üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì VIRTUAL

  • IN200 | Empower your agents to be responsible: Understand AI agent governance and security through SAP Integration Suite's API Management capabilities.
    üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì BERLIN | üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì VIRTUAL

üíª Application Development & Automation

  • AD820 | Future of app dev in SAP Build: Simplifying clean core and LoB extensions: Get exclusive previews of upcoming SAP Build enhancements including Joule copilot integration and improved developer productivity tools. 
    üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì BERLIN | üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì VIRTUAL

  • AD104 | Boost your ABAP development with SAP Joule for Developers: Learn how AI is transforming ABAP development with SAP Joule, from code acceleration to custom AI scenario development.
    üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì BERLIN | üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì VIRTUAL

  • IN160 | Empower your business through enterprise automation: Get hands-on experience combining SAP Integration Suite with SAP Build and SAP Signavio solutions. Learn to create automation-based integrations powered by AI capabilities and prebuilt content to drive process innovation.
    üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì BERLIN

 üîó Integration

  • IN100 | Make your enterprise future ready with SAP Integration Suite: Essential for anyone migrating from SAP PI/PO to SAP Integration Suite. Covers tools, best practices, and technical challenges with real-world insights. 
    üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì BERLIN | üóìÔ∏èADD NOW ‚Äì VIRTUAL

üîí Security & Compliance

entry.title: CAP at SAP TechEd 2025
entry.content:
Dear SAP community,

SAP TechEd 2025 is almost there! This year, SAP TechEd is a hybrid event: from November 4 ‚Äì 6 you can either join the in-person event in Berlin or the online event SAP TechEd Virtual. Hundreds of sessions, hands-on workshops, and networking opportunities are waiting for you.

If you didn‚Äôt already do it, save the date and register today: SAP TechEd Berlin | SAP TechEd Virtual!

In the session catalogs for the in-person and the virtual event, you will find a wide range of topics across various tracks. If you are interested in all the latest news around the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), let me guide you through my recommendations.

Keynote

KEY100 | Beyond the hype: How SAP is supercharging developers for what's next

Some experts argue there‚Äôs a developer shortage. Others will say developers are no longer needed due to AI. Let‚Äôs get real: developers, architects, and technologists are here to stay, and their roles are more important than ever. Explore how the latest technology, tools, AI, agents, and learning from SAP can help you adapt these changing roles.

This session is also available virtually: KEY100v.

Strategy Talk

ST116 | SAP Build for all: A shift toward AI-assisted developer-centric tools

Explore the most recent innovations in SAP Build solutions that help developers to create extensions, applications, and automations. Learn how enhancements in the development environment, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, and Joule copilot empower customers and partners to build extensions efficiently at scale.

This session is also available virtually: ST116v.

Roadmap Sessions

AD820 | Future of app dev in SAP Build: Simplifying Clean Core & LoB extensions‚Äã

Check out upcoming enhancements to SAP Build solutions involving SAP‚Äôs professional developer tools, the Joule copliot, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, SAPUI5, and SAP Fiori apps. These updates boost developer productivity, support clean core, and improve extensibility for line-of-business (LoB) apps, advancing enterprise app development.

This session is also available virtually: AD820v.

Deep Dive Sessions

AD101 | Integration of SAP Business Data Cloud with CAP and SAP Build‚Äã

The SAP Business Data Cloud solution unifies SAP and third-party data, and SAP Build solutions let you discover and use data products in the service center and consume them in apps based on SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). Get details on sharing data from these apps and using built-in tools for service-level integration.

AD203 | Fact checking UI Extensibility on top of CAP/RAP: What's in it for you?‚Äã

SAPUI5 flexibility lets you extend SAP Fiori apps in a clean core approach. Key users use drag-and-drop tools while developers add custom code with visual editors and the Joule copilot. See how SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and ABAP RESTful application programming model help extend data models and add custom logic in SAP Build solutions.

Hands-On Workshops:

AD160 | Get Hands-On with Joule: Boost Your SAP Build Development with AI‚Äã

The SAP Joule for Developers add-on brings AI capabilities directly into SAP Build solutions to support your development process. Get hands-on experience using AI-driven tools to boost your productivity in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and UI development, with features designed to simplify your workflow and help you build faster and smarter.                                                                            

AD161 | Integration of SAP Business Data Cloud with CAP and SAP Build‚Äã

Get hands-on experience with the SAP Business Data Cloud and SAP Build solutions to find out how to discover and use data products in apps based on SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). Practice sharing data from CAP apps and using built-in tools for service integration and SAP HANA‚Äìbased data federation.

AD260 | UI Extensibility on top of CAP/RAP: What's in it for you?‚Äã

SAPUI5 flexibility lets you extend SAP Fiori apps with a clean core approach. Key users and developers can add custom code with visual editors and Joule technology. See how SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and the ABAP RESTful application programming model support extending data models and adding custom logic in the SAP Build solution.

DT265 | Provision and extend multitenant solutions based on CAP for SAP Cloud ERP‚Äã

Experience how to provision, configure, and extend multitenant solutions based on SAP Business Technology Platform and the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) for SAP Cloud ERP. Using a reference example, you‚Äôll explore how to deliver customer-specific extensions on a scalable and resource-efficient multitenant architecture.

 

We can‚Äôt wait to see you at SAP TechEd 2025, either in Berlin or virtually!

entry.title: Info/Links for TechEd Community Talk CT1293 - SAP Build Control Tower
entry.content:
This post is to provide additional reference information and links related to my community talk CT1293 - Get control of the control tower feature in SAP Build solutions. See you there.

Control Tower Layout

Here's is the current picture of the Control Tower.

I think the layout is simple and clean, though it has evolved with additional tiles over the last 2 years and I don't think it's so clear how everything is inter-related. Here is my annotated version with a few notes. 

My notes:

  • Environments, introduced relatively recently with the public environment deprecated, seems to me the central most-important tile on the page
  • Destinations and API keys are strongly connected to environments
  • The first 3 tiles are related to transport: The first defines whether the tenant is dev/qa/prod for the sake of transport, and the governance rules (next 2 tiles) in part add an extra layer of approval for transport operations. The rules also affect simply creating a project.

More information on the Control Tower: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/managing-control-tower?locale=en-US

Permissions

There are many layers of permissions within SAP Build. Here they are from highest to lowest level.

IAS

Identity Authentication Service (IAS), or perhaps now just Cloud Identity Service, is the very first level and at the most basic level lets you create new users.

I just want to point out one helpful feature are groups. I can set up a group and then assign that group role connections. When I have a new user I just add them to the group and they inherent all the role collections. 

Here are groups in IAS.

Here I assign a group to a role collection. Note that SAP BTP does not have a dropdown of groups so you have to simply type in the name of the group.

YOu can do the same with attributes, for example, assign a role collection based on job function or home country.

More information: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/landing-page?locale=en-US

Tenants

Once you have a user in IAS, you can assign that user to a tenant and NOT assign them to other tenants. You can look in the Users page to see which users have access to the current tenant.

More information: https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/business-users?locale=en-US

Roles

Once a user has access to the tenant in some way, you determine what they can do on that tenant by assigning them roles, not directly, but through role collections, which are sets of roles that loosely map to a persona (e.g., admin, developer, business user, super user).

Here's more information on the specific roles/role collections related to the low-code tools of SAP Build:

  • SAP Build Apps: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-apps/service-guide/configuring-user-roles?locale=en-US&q=role
  • SAP Build Process Automation: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/authorizations?locale=en-US&q=role
  • SAP Build Work Zone: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-standard-edition/sap-build-work-zone-standard-edition/about-roles-and-role-assignments?locale=en-US&q=role

Design-Time Authorizations

These authorizations are done on the project level, some know as collaboration authorizations, so you can work with others on specific projects.

For information on the meaning of each role, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/managing-project-members?locale=en-US.

Runtime Automarizations

Runtime authorizations are the authorizations you have within environments. Environments are separate areas for deploying projects, and each environment can be set up to allow different users to do different activities (e.g., view, deploy, add users).

For information on the meaning of each role, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/share-environment.

Governance Rules

Governance rules let you set up a process to be executed so managers can approve or reject whether another user can create a project or transport a project.

If you enable rules for either creation or transport, you are automatically given into the lobby an out-of-the-box process and action. You must deploy the process before the rules can take effect (the action is automatically published). Before deploying, you can modify the process -- you really must since it the process automatically gives the requestor the right to approve his own project.

For more information, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/governance?locale=en-US&q=governance+rules.

Transport

Transport allows you to create formal processes for moving projects from one tenant to another tenant, generally from DEV > QA > PROD. The transport does not deploy projects but simply moves the design-time projects from one SAP Build installation to another. You can only transport a released version.

You will have to install Cloud Transport Manager Service, and add the Content Agent Service on every tenant to which you want to transport content. 

Once you have everything setup and execute a transport from the SAP Build lobby, the package goes to CTMS, where someone with the import role will need to approve the transport. 

For more information on setting up transport, see https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/transporting-content-in-sap-build-apps-sap-cloud-transport-management/ba-p/13737478.

For more information on how to transport and prerequisites, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build/sap-build-core/transport-project?locale=en-US&q=transport.

entry.title: How Redwood Software and SAP are shaping the next era of automation with Joule Studio
entry.content:
Introduction

Over the past year, Redwood Software has taken major steps forward in our long-standing partnership with SAP, turning the vision of conversational, agentic automation into something you can see and use today.

As Field CTO at Redwood, I‚Äôve spent many years helping SAP customers orchestrate their most critical workloads. Our shared mission with SAP has always been clear: make complex processes simpler, more reliable and, ultimately, autonomous.

Embedding automation into conversation with Joule Studio

In my previous post, I introduced how RunMyJobs by Redwood connects with SAP Joule Studio to transform automation into natural conversation. Since then, we‚Äôve built a tech preview that demonstrates a use case for how RunMyJobs‚Äô interoperability with SAP Joule makes agentic orchestration a reality you can scale for your most mission-critical processes.

One example is an autonomous, unplanned SAP system maintenance workflow. Traditionally, this requires multiple manual steps and cross-team coordination to pause background jobs, stop dependent integrations and verify dependencies. The SAP BTP team often has to schedule, stop or undeploy iFlows ad hoc, while the Basis team handles job suspension separately. Thus, it‚Äôs a fragmented process filled with stress and risk.

Today, an SAP Basis administrator can take a more goal-oriented approach. They can simply tell Joule what they need to do: 

‚ÄúSafely execute the SAP system maintenance procedure, including a pause on all dependent workflows associated with the system to avoid job failures.‚Äù

Joule triggers the complete, pre-approved workflow across RunMyJobs and the relevant SAP systems. Acting as an interactive control tower for the entire event, it executes pre-approved RunMyJobs workflows, coordinates with integrations and provides real-time progress and approval updates through natural language with either business or IT users.

For example, Joule might respond: 

‚ÄúAll background jobs are paused, and Integration Suite iFlows are offline. Do you approve the system restart now, or do you want to send an approval request to the system administrator for a restart?‚Äù 

Once the administrator confirms, the automated workflow proceeds to the next step.

üëâSee Joule in action with RunMyJobs here:

 

What we learned building Joule skills

Working with Joule Studio‚Äôs low-code design canvas confirmed how quickly governed automation can be delivered through conversational interfaces. Our approach focused on four essentials:

  1. Natural conversation design: Translating how SAP users actually phrase requests into machine-understandable prompts
  2. Action orchestration: Linking RunMyJobs APIs or pre-built SAP Accelerator Hub actions for pausing jobs, managing iFlows and performing restarts safely
  3. Context and safeguards: Supplying metadata so Joule executes only on the right systems, with test harnesses for edge cases
  4. Governed deployment: Leveraging accelerated compliance checks provided by RunMyJobs‚Äô SAP Endorsed App Premium certification to reliably execute controlled deployment across SAP environments

How RunMyJobs and Joule Studio connect

The integration between RunMyJobs and Joule Studio allows your teams to innovate safely across SAP environments and in various scenarios. The process looks like this:

  1. Publish operations in RunMyJobs, such as starting or pausing jobs.
  2. Publish actions to the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, making them available as reusable building blocks. 
  3. Secure access through SAP BTP using API keys and role-based permissions. You then govern access to these operations within the SAP BTP Cockpit. 
  4. Combine these actions in Joule Studio to build skills that connect automation with natural language requests.

This framework lets IT and business teams interact with automation directly in their workflow tools, so it‚Äôs governed, auditable and ready for expansion.

The future of automation is a conversation

We are only at the starting line of what‚Äôs possible. The combination of RunMyJobs and SAP Joule is laying the foundation for agentic automation across finance, supply chain, HR, IT and beyond. As SAP continues to advance its Business AI capabilities, Redwood will keep embedding orchestration where it matters most: within the business conversation.

Learn more about how Redwood works with SAP solutions.

entry.title: The Joule Studio Learning Series: Lead Agentic Development with Confidence
entry.content:
Organizations are adopting agentic AI to transform how work gets done. Joule Studio offers developers a low code, no code environment to design and deploy secure, scalable, and interoperable Joule agents that plan and execute workflows in a heterogenous landscape. 

To help you get started, I‚Äôve created a four-part enablement video series that walks you through everything: from understanding what Joule Studio is to building Joule agents. Whether you‚Äôre just getting started or an experienced developer, this series will help you transform business workflows with the power agentic AI and Joule Studio. By the end of this enablement series, you‚Äôll have an understanding of: 

  • Joule Studio: its marketecture and capabilities   
  • Joule agents and skills: definition, characteristics, and use cases
  • How to build, test, and deploy your own Joule agents and skills

What is Joule Studio? 

Start your learning journey with an introduction to Joule Studio, underlying components, and how it enables the creation of adaptive, intelligent agents for business workflows.

You‚Äôll learn: 

  • What Joule Studio is and what problems it solves 
  • Key capabilities and components 
  • The value Joule Studio delivers

 

 

What Are AI Agents and Joule Skills? 

Dive into the fundamentals. Understand the building blocks of Joule Studio: AI agents and Joule skills, how they work together, their characteristics, and use cases. 

You‚Äôll learn: 

  • Difference between Joule skills and AI agents 
  • How AI agents work 
  • Common use cases for both 

 

Creating a Joule Skill in Joule Studio 

In this hands-on demo, learn how to create a Joule skill within SAP Build using Joule Studio for predictable execution of rule-based, repetitive tasks. The example walks through creating an ID badge in a third-party system after performing a preliminary check in SAP.  

You‚Äôll learn: 

  • How to configure inputs and outputs for a Joule skill 
  • How to connect SAP and external systems 
  • How to configure messages to Joule 

 

Creating Joule Agents in Joule Studio 

See the agent builder capability in Joule Studio in action. This video shows how to create and configure a Joule agent end-to-end, equipping it with tools, models, and other configurations for adaptive execution in a business scenario. 

You‚Äôll learn: 

  • How to create and test Joule agent 
  • How to configure tools, models, and skills 

 

Get Started with Joule Studio 

Ready to build your first agent? Check out additional documentation and resources to get started: 

  • How to get started with Joule Studio 
  • The Complete Joule Studio Resource Hub

entry.title: Build Business-Grounded AI Agents, Faster
entry.content:
At Sapphire 2025, SAP announced Joule Studio, a capability in SAP Build that enables developers to create Joule agents and skills. Deeply grounded in business data, these agents orchestrate workflows across heterogenous landscapes to deliver accurate outcomes. Joule Studio delivers an agent runtime with built-in data protection guardrails, multi-LLM support, and context retention across tasks for scalable, secure execution.  

Today, we are announcing additional capabilities that will equip developers with a comprehensive development tool kit to build scalable agentic AI for their business. We are introducing vibe coding experience to create not only conversational but also system-triggered AI agents. Instead of building from scratch, developers can also extend ready-to-use Joule agents as per their business needs. Joule Studio will also support open standards such as Model Context Protocol (MCP) and Agent2Agent (A2A) protocol. These advances empower developers to deliver end-to-end agentic automation with greater speed, flexibility, and control. See what our customers and partners from the beta program (Q3 2025) have to say: 

‚ÄúWith Joule Studio, we could build powerful agents in three weeks. It is an intuitive, no‚Äëcode environment that enables system connectivity across SAP and non‚ÄëSAP critical environments, for a hybrid landscapes where data resides in multiple modules.‚Äù 

 - Gianluca Simeone, VP - Global SAP CTIO and Gen-AI Leader at Capgemini 

‚ÄúNestle, SAP, and IBM worked together on a supply chain Agentic AI PoC. With the agent builder capability in Joule Studio, we created this POC bringing in data from SAP and non-SAP sources to create an agent that will automate our complex Order fulfillment processes‚Äù  

- Pablo Nill, Sr Product Group Manager, Nestle  

 ‚ÄúWith Joule Studio, agentic innovation moves closer to the heart of operations. At KPMG, we‚Äôre helping to shape trusted solutions that transform business context into measurable value by building specialized AI agents for fulfillment orchestration, supply chain management, and more‚Äù. 

 - Valentino K√∂ster, Global Head of SAP360 Program & AI, KPMG AG WPG, Germany 

Fast‚ÄëTracking Ideas into Agents: Empowering Developers with AI 

To lower the barrier to AI adoption, Joule Studio provides AI assistance in the design-time experience of creating agents. Developers can use natural language to share their requirements with Joule copilot and get contextual recommendations for agent definition, tools, and other configurations, tailored to their specific needs. For example, Joule may suggest and add relevant Joule skills to custom Joule agents. This makes agent creation more accessible and accelerates time-to-value. 

Image 1: AI-assistance in Joule Studio

Cross-Ecosystem Integration with Model Context Protocol (MCP) 

One of the most significant updates is Joule Studio‚Äôs support for MCP, an open standard that provides a unified way to connect AI agents with external systems. This breaks down traditional application silos and enables cross-platform agent execution. In Joule Studio, you can configure connectivity to external MCP servers, allowing agents to use third-party tools and applications. For example, a support agent that you built in Joule Studio can retrieve ticket information from a third-party IT service platform exposed via MCP. This open integration empowers AI agents to act as central, intelligent orchestrators, managing complex workflows across diverse systems without the need for custom integrations.  

Image 2: Configuration of tools, MCP servers, and models for agent design

Proactive Agentic Automation with System-Triggered Agents 

Joule Studio will support the creation of system-triggered AI agents that operate autonomously with no human input. Triggers such as business events, APIs, and schedules will be supported for agents to be initiated. This elevates agents from being reactive to proactive collaborators, capable of initiating actions like inventory monitoring and initiating purchase orders for low stock items or incident response. That enables true end-to-end automation of business processes with minimal human intervention.  

Image 3: Add triggers for custom agents

Adapt Pre-Built, SAP-Delivered Agents to Your Enterprise  

In Joule Studio, developers will be able to extend ready-to-use Joule agents by adding additional tools and custom skills as pre- and post-processing steps. For example, extend an Accounts Receivable Agent, which analyzes overdue receivables and follows up with customers, by grounding it in your order handling policy for informed decision making. This allows you to tailor ready-to-use Joule agents to your unique business requirements.

Image 4: Extending ready-to-use Joule agents 

Getting Started with agent builder in Joule Studio

The agent builder will be generally available in December 2025 with support for MCP, agent as a tool, vibe coding, and document grounding part of first release. Later in 2026, we will release support for agent extensibility, system-triggered agents, A2A, and agent observability. 

If you are interested in learning more:

  • Register for the webinar for a closer look at agent builder experience: Link
  • Visit the Joule Studio webpage: Link
  • Checkout demo on building Joule agents in Joule Studio: Demo

entry.title: From Skill to Agent: Building a Legal Payment-Solicitation Letter with Joule Studio
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning on a Joule Studio experimental environment. The final version that will be released may provide a different set of capabilities.

Introduction

Finance teams spend valuable time preparing formal demand letters: finding the correct legal recipient, composing language that satisfies local legal requirements, and ensuring consistent formatting. Joule Studio (part of SAP Build) lets you automate these steps using modular Skills and orchestrating Agents ‚Äî while preserving governance and auditability.

This article walks through a complete pattern: configure secure connectivity to S/4HANA, build the Get Customer Information Skill, then compose the Credit Collection Specialis that generates language-specific legal letters ready for review and sending.

Quick definitions

Joule Skill

A focused, reusable function with defined inputs and outputs. Example: retrieve a customer‚Äôs legal name and address from S/4HANA.

Joule Agent

An intelligent orchestrator that invokes Skills, makes decisions, handles user interactions, and produces business outcomes (for example: draft a legal letter, request approval, send the letter, and log the result).

Use case: Legal payment-solicitation letter

Goal: allow a collections specialist to enter a customer number, debt amount and language ‚Äî and receive a legally formatted demand letter populated with S/4HANA legal data.

Inputs: customer_number, debt_amount, language
Outputs: Draft legal letter (text format).

We will build:

  • Skill: CustomerLegalDataFetcher ‚Äî fetches legal name & address from S/4HANA.
  • Agent: PaymentSolicitationAgent ‚Äî orchestrates retrieval and generates the letter text in the selected language.

Step 0 ‚Äî Configure secure connectivity (BTP Destination & Action Project)

Before the Skill can call S/4HANA, set up a Destination in BTP and an Action Project in SAP Build to expose the needed API in a governed way.

Create a Destination in SAP BTP Cockpit

  1. Log in to SAP BTP cockpit ‚Üí Subaccount ‚Üí Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations ‚Üí New Destination.
  2. Name: S4HANA_BP. Type: HTTP. URL: your S/4HANA API base (e.g. https://.../sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER).
  3. Proxy Type: Internet (or OnPremise if using Cloud Connector). Select Authentication (OAuth2ClientCredentials or BasicAuth) and provide credentials or client info.
  4. Optional properties: sap-client, HTML5.DynamicDestination=true, WebIDEEnabled=true,sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled=treu,sap.processautomation.enabled=true. Save and Check Connection.

Create an Action Project in SAP Build

  1. Open SAP Build, move to Actions window (selecting it on the left hand side menu) and click on the Create button. 
  2. Go to API Specification and select SAP Business Accelerator Hub.  Here you can find the Business Partner (A2X) API specification.  Select it and click on Next button.  Assign a name to the project: S4HANA_Customer_Actions Connections and provide a description. Click on Create button.
  3. Select the API calls to be added to the project. For the purpose of this implementation, you can select Retrieves customer general data and Retrieves business partner address data.  
  4. After adding them to the project, the Action editing GUI appears, providing  the ability to fine tune the inputs and the outputs of your actions.
  5. You can test the Actions selecting the name of the destination you created before. After finalizing the Actions, you need to Release and Publish the project.

Result: your Action is published and available to be called from a Joule Skill.

Step 1 ‚Äî Build the Skill: Credit Collection Letter

A. Create the Skill project

  1. From the SAP Build Lobby,  Create  ‚Üí Joule Skill ‚Üí Name: Credit Collection Letter. 
  2. Now, from the Joule Studio main page: Create  ‚Üí Joule Skill ‚Üí Name: Get Customer Information
  3.  Assign a meaningful description, such as: A skill to retrieve Customer information from a S/4HANA system, providing as input the Customer Number.
  4. Define the input parameter of the skill (CustomerNumber) and the output parameters (CustomerLegalName, streetName, houseNumber, cityName, postalCode and country).

B. Call the Action

  1. Add two Call Action step ‚Üí choose S4HANA_Customer_Actions and the customer and address lookup actions.
  2. Map inputs/outputs between Skill and Action. 
  3. In the End step, map the output of the Action calls to the skill's output parameters.

C. Test the Skill

Before testing the skill, you need to create an environment and to associate the destination to this environment:

  1. From the SAP Build Lobby,  open the Control Tower from the menu on the left hand side.
  2. Open the Environments page. You can find it in the Tenant Configuration section. 
  3. Click on the Activate Private Environment button. 
  4. Go back to the Control Tower and open the Destinations page. You can find it in the Backend Configuration section.
  5. Find the destination you defined in the BTP Cockpit, open the Actions menu on the right side and select Associate Environments.
  6. Now you can associate the destination to the private environment you activated in step #3.

Once the environment has been created, with an associated destination, from the Skill editing page you can test the skill clicking on the Test button. Select your private environment and the destination. The Joule prompting page is displayed and you can send some prompts to test the Skill. 

 

 

Step 2 ‚Äî Build the Agent: Credit Collection Specialist

A. Create the Agent

  1. From the Joule Studio main page: Create  ‚Üí Joule Agent ‚Üí Name: Credit Collection Specialist
  2. Add a description, such as: Writer of reminder letters for unpaid debts
  3. Now in the Agent Builder page, you need to fill the Expertise, the Instructions and the Additional Context text boxes. Tip #1: in the instructions, please specify that the Get Customer Information skill should be used for retrieving the customer's information. Tip #2: Provide an example of the letter you want it writes.
  4. Chose the LLM model to be used, selecting between the available ones.
  5. In the Tools section, add the Get Customer Information skill as a tool to be used.

‚ÄÉ

B. Attach Tools

  • In the Tools section, add the Get Customer Information skill as a tool to be used.

C. Test and Deploy the Agent

  1. Save the Agent and click on the Test button. Select your private environment and the destination.
  2. The Joule prompting page is displayed and you can send some prompts to test the Agent. 
  3. Once the Agent is fully debugged, you can Release and Deploy the project to one of the environments available. If necessary, you can create a new environment from the Control Tower.

Security, governance & integration notes

Use service credentials or OAuth client credentials for the Destination. Limit Destination editing to admins, and ensure Cloud Connector is configured if S/4HANA is on-premise. Maintain a clear change-control process for legal templates ‚Äî any change must trigger regression tests of the Agent.

Conclusion & call to action

By separating retrieval (Skill) from orchestration (Agent), you make the solution reusable, testable and governable. Users simply provide the customer number, amount and language ‚Äî Joule handles the rest, identifying the Agent and the Skill to be used: fetch data and generate compliant letter text that can be cut and pasted into a Word document.

And that‚Äôs all for today! Now you can continue reading other posts on the SAP Community Blogs: https://community.sap.com/t5/all-sap-community-blogs/ct-p/all-blogs

entry.title: Announcing New SAP Build and Service Catalog Extensions for VS Code
entry.content:
SAP is committed to ‚Äúmeeting developers where they are‚Äù and recently SAP unveiled new MCP servers for SAP Build, demonstrating SAP‚Äôs dedication to that Vision.  

By adopting these new MCP standards, developers can seamlessly extend SAP‚Äôs development capabilities into multiple development environments, ensuring flexibility and choice by enhancing popular agentic development solutions.

Now SAP is going even further, and I am happy to share that we have now released new extensions to the VS Code marketplace, marking what is sure to be just the beginning of a transformative journey.

With the expansion of SAP Build‚Äôs productivity tools available as VS Code extensions, SAP is shaping the end-to-end experience and empowering the professional developers to choose whatever tools suits them better while leveraging the power of SAP development frameworks, integrations and accelerators.

Service Catalog Extension

This extension will provide a central location for exploring and consuming services in a highly efficient and harmonious manner, enhancing both development speed and quality.  This will be the local implementation of the well-known service center found in SAP Business Application Studio. The initial release focusses on the ABAP catalog and on-premise systems, supporting basic authentication and seamless integration with Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) applications. Next year we plan to add support for exploration and consumption of Data Products from SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Keep in mind that you must also install the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Tools extension to take advantage of CAP application integration.

SAP Build Full-Stack Extension Pack

This pack bundles all available tools for SAP Build full-stack application development. It will make it easier and faster for developers to find and install the tools they can use to enhance their end-to-end development experience. You can expect all forthcoming SAP Build Full-Stack productivity tools released by SAP, such as the Storyboard planned for release next year, to be incorporated into this pack.

SAP is investing in both, the improvement of the current onboarding experience with the full-stack pack and the release of ongoing innovation of development tools for the VS Code marketplace.

Looking ahead, SAP plans to provide seamless integration with SAP APIs and platform services, thereby optimizing the development experience for its community, and to release BTP extensions to the open VSX registry to make getting started with SAP Build development easier with other popular agentic development solutions, further enriching the diverse development ecosystem.

We are thrilled about the possibilities these new tools bring to the development community and look forward to witnessing the innovative solutions they will inspire.
Don‚Äôt miss the opportunity to be at the forefront of innovation and try out our new extensions now!

entry.title: Effortless SAPUI5 Patch Management: Introducing the New SAPUI5 Runtime Repository
entry.content:
For years, the MIME repository has been the standard location for storing SAPUI5 runtime artifacts for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. In contrast, the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition retrieves SAPUI5 from the cloud CDN. Although the MIME repository has served its purpose, many customers working with SAPUI5, especially system operators installing new SAPUI5 patches, face common challenges. These include poor performance, numerous manual steps, issues with transports, and risk of inconsistent states.

The good news is that SAP introduces the SAPUI5 Runtime Repository with the release of SAP S/4HANA 2025. This modern replacement overcomes these challenges and prepares you for the next generation of SAPUI5. To ensure efficiency for all customers, downports to all maintained lower releases are available, except for SAP S/4HANA 1809 using SAPUI5 1.38. You can access this repository through SAP Notes containing transport-based correction instructions (TCIs).

Let's explore how this new repository significantly enhances your workflow.

Performance Where It Matters

  • MIME Repository: SAPUI5 patch updates can take up to 2 hours. Loading debug-sources with sap-ui-debug=true can take up to 10 minutes.
  • SAPUI5 Runtime Repository: Patch upgrades are approximately 20 times faster. During runtime, loading debug sources also occurs about 20 times faster. These improvements ensure smoother operations and faster response times.

From Complexity to Simplicity

  • MIME Repository: Handles more than 70,000 individual ABAP objects. This volume poses a risk of errors and inconsistent updates.
  • SAPUI5 Runtime Repository: All runtime content is bundled into just one ABAP object. This approach guarantees consistent updates and reduces operational risks.

Automation First

  • MIME Repository: Updates rely on custom, manual procedures, which increases the maintenance effort.
  • SAPUI5 Runtime Repository: Uses SAP TCI Notes and comes with an automated process specifically for SAP S/4HANA cloud operations. This makes updates easier and more reliable.

Zero Downtime Deployments

  • MIME Repository: No support for zero-downtime deployments. This limitation might cause interruptions during system upgrades.
  • SAPUI5 Runtime Repository: Fully supports online deployment with zero downtime. This feature ensures that SAPUI5 content remains continuously available, even during system upgrades.

Safe, Standardized Rollbacks

  • MIME Repository: Reverting patches can be error-prone, often requiring manual fixes and risking inconsistent system states.
  • SAPUI5 Runtime Repository: Reverting SAPUI5 patches is fully supported. Runtime content is delivered as a single ABAP object, and the update process integrates with TCIs. Rollbacks are straightforward, consistent, and safe. This approach simplifies the validation of new patches: if issues arise, you can reliably revert to the previous stable state without lengthy manual intervention or risking inconsistencies across systems.

Future-Proof 

  • MIME Repository: Not compatible with multiple SAPUI5 versions.
  • SAPUI5 Runtime Repository: Supports multiple SAPUI5 versions in parallel, making it ready for the future while ensuring backward compatibility.

Here's an overview of all the improvements:

Why This Matters

The move from MIME Repository to the new SAPUI5 Runtime Repository isn‚Äôt just a technical upgrade ‚Äî it‚Äôs a significant step toward:

  • Faster and safer patch updates.
  • Reduced operational effort.
  • Continuous availability.
  • Future compatibility.

If your organization uses on-premise landscapes and works with SAPUI5, it's time to embrace this change: the SAPUI5 Runtime Repository becomes automatically available with the current SAP S/4HANA 2025 release and in the latest support packages of all maintained SAP S/4HANA versions except SAP S/4HANA 1809.

Even if you do not want to upgrade to a new support package, you can still use the SAPUI5 runtime repository by installing SAP Note 3599156. If you have hesitated to install a new SAPUI5 patch, now is the time to try the new procedure and benefit from its efficacy and ease. Installing the latest SAPUI5 patches ensures your applications run efficiently today and are prepared for the future.

üëâHave you performed any SAPUI5 patch upgrades recently? What has your experience been like so far? To get started, refer to SAP Note 3599156.

entry.title: How AI is Transforming Your Digital Workspace
entry.content:
How AI is Transforming Your Digital Workspace

Introduction

The modern workplace has changed dramatically. Employees no longer rely solely on static intranets or scattered collaboration tools. Instead, they expect a connected, personalized experience that helps them cut through the noise and focus on meaningful work. Enter artificial intelligence (AI).

AI isn‚Äôt just another layer of technology- it‚Äôs rapidly becoming the backbone of digital workspaces. By surfacing the right information at the right time, automating repetitive tasks, and enabling smarter collaboration and self-service, AI is redefining how we work, learn, and engage every day.

With digital workspaces in SAP Build, these AI capabilities are already available today‚Äîhelping organizations deliver intelligent, personalized employee experiences out of the box

The Rise of AI in the Digital Workspace

For years, digital workspaces have been a central hub for business applications, documents, apps, and communications in one place. Useful‚Äîbut often overwhelming. Employees spent as much time searching for information as they did, acting on it.

Now, AI is filling the gaps. With intelligent copilots, content curation, and contextual answers, digital workspaces like SAP Build Work Zone have evolved from being a destination for information into an engine for productivity and engagement.

Core AI features available today in SAP Build digital workspaces

1. Chatbots & Virtual Assistants
With Joule, SAP‚Äôs AI copilot, workspace users can access information instantly. From answering HR questions to surfacing insights from reports, employees can rely on conversational AI to get what they need instantaneously.

Joule, SAP's AI copilot integrated into the digital workspace

2. Task completion with Joule Skills

One can enhance Joule capabilities by creating skills for it in Joule Studio. Connected with SAP systems and third-party applications, Joule can complete tasks like submitting time-off requests, approving workflows, or surfacing KPI dashboards‚Äîall from a single interface

  

3. Document Grounding Capabilities
Joule ensures information is both contextual and reliable when using workspace content to ground AI responses. For example, employees can ask ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs our travel policy in Europe?‚Äù and receive an AI response sourced directly from workspace content or SAP SuccessFactors policies when it is enabled as an AI source.

  

4. Content generation and summarization using generative AI
SAP Build leverages generative AI to help users create and refine content‚Äîwhether drafting announcements, summarizing updates, or suggesting language for a blog post‚Äîdirectly within the workspace.

  

 

 

 

 

Real-Life Examples in Action

  • Information access with grounded responses

Joule responds with answers grounded in the specific workspace content. Employees can query Joule with specific questions like ‚ÄúWhat is the holiday plan for next year in Germany" or ‚Äúhow can I apply for a sabbatical leave? Point me to the relevant file‚Äù.

  • Smart document summaries

Integrated AI services capture the highlights of a workspace document‚Äîpolicy highlights, key insights from data, or high-level overview of a blog.

  • Workflow Automation

From within SAP Build workspace, an employee can ask Joule to ‚Äúcreate a purchase order‚Äù or ‚Äúshow current pipeline metrics.‚Äù The copilot triggers the workflow in connected SAP systems, making productivity seamless.

  • Intelligent content curation

Users can easily create blog posts, feed posts or even knowledge articles in the workspace using the native AI features with simple prompts like ‚Äúcreate a workspace feed reminding members to fill their timesheet in a funny and casual tone‚Äù.

The Business Impact

  • Faster Information Access: Joule makes information searches 95% faster by surfacing insights and data instantly. Grounded insights reduce time spent searching for answers.
  • Reduced Manual Effort: Generative AI-assisted summarization and content creation free up employee time.
  • Better Governance: AI responses in SAP are backed by enterprise content, ensuring compliance and accuracy.

Preparing for the AI-Powered Workspace

Adopting AI in digital workspaces is not just about flipping a switch‚Äîit‚Äôs about preparing your organization:

  • Change Management: Train employees to adopt AI workflows and copilots in their daily work.
  • Governance: Define guardrails for AI-generated content, data privacy, and security.
  • Integration: Maximize value by connecting SAP Build with existing SAP and non-SAP applications, making copilots more powerful.

Conclusion

AI is no longer a future trend; it‚Äôs already embedded in the digital workspaces employees use today. With embedded AI and Joule, organizations don‚Äôt just imagine an intelligent workspace‚Äîthey experience it

By weaving AI into daily workflows‚Äîwhether through copilots, recommended learning, or curated content‚ÄîSAP Build helps organizations unlock productivity, agility, and engagement at scale.

Ready to take the next step?

Learn more about these capabilities and their implementation from the following resources:

  1. Joule integration with Work Zone
  2. SAP Build Work Zone Gets Even More Powerful with AI-Powered Capabilities
  3. Set Up Document Grounding | SAP Help Portal
  4. Integration With Document Grounding | SAP Help Portal
  5. Enabling AI Features | SAP Help Portal
